analytic.title: RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: One of the markers of human cognitive agency is the capacity for moral cognition. Across a range of societies, older adults are perceived as more moral than younger adults. Interestingly, research shows that compared to younger adults, older adults are more likely to endorse deontological (as opposed to utilitarian) ethics. This age difference has been explained in terms of cognitive decline and socioemotional shifts. In this paper, I consider the Exploration-Exploitation (EE) model of aging, as well as the Relevance Realization (RR) framework, in explaining moral decision-making phenomena across younger and older adults. My analysis reveals that in older age, the mechanisms underlying moral decision-making gravitate toward efficiency-based processing more generally, as opposed to exploitation-based processing more specifically, thereby lending support in favour of the RR framework over the EE model of aging. I conclude that in light of the explanatory breadth offered by RR, the opponency of explorationexploitation alone, a trade-off relationship subsumed by RR, is at times necessary but insufficient in explaining age differences in response to sacrificial moral dilemmas. Accordingly, I suggest that augmenting EE with RR could expand both its theoretical precision and explanatory power, while ameliorating its possible theoretical blind spots. I conclude by discussing the empirical limitations of the RR framework and proposing potential empirical avenues for future research on RR in the context of moral decision-making.

div.p: yet its method of propelling forward is less than one percent effective. In viewing the paramecium as a situated biological whole-that is, an entity that does not merely exist, but organizes itself in response to a dynamic environment-we see that the bacterial cell gravitates toward areas that have greater concentrations of sugar, both by conducting random searchers and following gradients (Thompson, 2007). When no sugar gradients are detectable, the cell allows itself to get carried by water currents until it detects the necessary sustenance. At this point, it activates its cilia and swims toward sugar to replenish itself and repeat this cycle. In this way, the paramecium is autopoietic, a term that describes a system that has the capacity to maintain its structural integrity by extracting the necessary external resources from its environment to sustain itself (Maturana & Varela, 1991). The paramecium does not abide by physical laws; rather, the norms that allow for survival emerge from its organization (Hovhannisyan, 2023;Thompson 2011;. Its need for sugar is not inherent to sugar either but instead arises as a relational property between the molecular structure of sugar and the paramecium's biological organization, necessitating sugar as a source of energy for autopoiesis.

It may appear like an odd choice to open a comprehensive paper on moral decisionmaking and aging by describing an obscure microscopic organism that floats around in still waters. But if it is the case that human evolution began with a single cell, then the properties possessed by a primitive organism like the paramecium ought to be embedded in more complex RELEVANCE REALIZATION,AGING, organisms, like human beings, as well (Hovhannisyan, 2023;Thompson, 2007;Varela et al., 1991). For present purposes, the overlapping characteristic of interest between the paramecium and human beings is that of cognitive agency. Indeed, by studying the paramecium, we come to understand that a defining characteristic of organisms is that they constitutively realize what is relevant for their autopoiesis through their interactions with the environment (Hovhannisyan & Dewey, 2017;Hovhannisyan & Vervaeke, 2022;Thompson, 2007;Varela et al., 1991;Vervaeke et al., 2012). This is to say, the paramecium exemplifies a central characteristic of cognitive agency that is shared by human beings as well, although in a tremendously more articulated form, namely the ability to "zero in on relevant aspects of the world" while ignoring noise that is irrelevant to goals that serve its self-preservation (Andersen et al., 2022, p. 1). Now, let us zoom out from this microscopic view, fast forward by four billion years (UCSB ScienceLine, 2018), and situate ourselves in the Garden of Eden, where there is now man, and man is a self-organizing cognitive agent who has committed a moral transgression against God by consuming the forbidden fruit from the tree of knowledge of good and evil (New International Version Bible [NIV], 2011, Genesis 3). The story of Adam and Eve is a wellknown illustration of the first sinners in human history, reaching audiences far beyond followers of Abrahamic religions. For our interests, the significance of this biblical story does not lie in its theological implications. Rather, it is meant to highlight a vitally important dimension of our own cognitive agency: the moral dimension. Unlike the paramecium, we are not simply motivated to survive by seeking sources of sugar in our environment. But like Adam and Eve, our day-to-day decisions are predominantly governed by implicit or explicit understandings of what is right or wrong, good or bad. RELEVANCE REALIZATION,AGING, Moral psychologists typically study moral decision-making by examining how people respond to and navigate moral dilemmas. In this context, moral dilemmas are less concerned with the consequences of disobeying a God, and instead attempt to elucidate the ethical frameworks humans adopt when engaged in moral decision-making. Two commonly studied ethical frameworks undergirding people's decisions are deontology and utilitarianism.

Deontology suggests that an act is good or bad according to a set of predefined rules; as such, acts that align with the rules are moral, while those that do not are immoral. On the other hand, utilitarianism differentiates right and wrong by focusing on the outcomes, arguing that the ethical choice is the one that maximizes good for the greatest number of people. Moral psychologists frequently use the Trolley Problem to gauge inclinations toward either ethical theory. This is a scenario in which a malfunctioning trolley is about to run over five people, but the bystander (i.e., the research participant) can intervene and divert it to the other track where there is only one person. The deontological agent's response to this dilemma would be to refrain from acting, arguing that if killing people is wrong, then it is wrong across all contexts. The utilitarian agent would opt to divert the trolley, killing one person to save five others as a means of maximizing good and minimizing harm. There are countless iterations of the trolley dilemma, whereby the individual victim may be a family member, a future Nobel prize winner, or a surgeon who saves lives daily. Some variations involve alterations to the track in which the train loops around, connecting to the alternate track with five people (Bago & De Neys, 2019;Greene et al., 2001). 1
For our purposes, we will primarily focus on the classic depiction of sacrificial dilemmas.
A particularly reliable observation made by moral psychologists concerns differences in ethical leanings during sacrificial moral dilemmas like the trolley problem (utilitarian vs.

1 Find here an entertaining website dedicated to Absurd Trolley Problems: https://neal.fun/absurd-trolley-problems/ RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 7 deontological) among younger vs. older adults (Daley & Kensinger, 2021;Huang et al., 2021b;McNair et al., 2019). Specifically, when faced with sacrificial moral dilemmas, older adults are more likely to engage in deontological reasoning than younger adults. From a psychological perspective, this immediately raises the question as to whether observed age differences in moral decision-making can be explained as a function of differences in underlying psychological mechanisms between younger vs. older adulthood. The literature on this topic is vast. Thus, I
begin by focusing on current cognitive and socioemotional accounts of moral decision-making.

My discussion of this literature underscores the fact that despite the numerous explanations for the aging trends in question, there is a lack of a unified understanding of how these two levels of analysis (i.e., cognitive or socioemotional) ought to be related to and integrated with one another, leaving research in the field in a fragmented and potentially confused state.

To address this issue, I turn to a recent account by Spreng and Turner (2021) that promises to deliver a unified understanding of human aging. By bringing together research on decision-making and the neuroscience of aging, as well as cognitive and affective aging theories, the authors argue that all volitional acts can be reduced to the choice to either exploit prior knowledge toward a more predictable outcome or to explore new sources of information that have more unpredictable returns. They call this the shifting mental mode hypothesis of aging, which postulates that exploration-exploitation trade-offs increasingly lean toward exploitation (over exploration) in older adulthood.

Despite their claim that all volitional acts can be reduced to either the choice to explore or the choice to exploit, I find there is evidence of other trade-offs at play in cognition that are just as fundamental as the exploration-exploitation trade-off. I make my case by turning to recent work by Vervaeke et al. (2012) that has sought to explain cognitive agency in terms of three RELEVANCE REALIZATION,AGING, trade-off relationships, subsumed under one overarching trade-off relationship, rather than just one of exploration-exploitation. The authors refer to their framework as a theory of relevance realization (RR) because it explains how cognition can effectively zero-in on relevant information while ignoring noise, thereby circumventing the notorious frame problem in cognitive science (discussed in Section "Relevance Realization as a Theory of Cognitive Function"). In this way, Vervaeke et al.'s (2012) theory of RR can not only benefit Spreng and Turner (2021) in their aim to be truly comprehensive but can also benefit our own project of explaining the trends observed in younger vs. older adults' moral decision-making in the context of sacrificial moral dilemmas.

To support this claim, upon reviewing both Spreng and Turner's (2021) explore-exploit (EE) model and Vervaeke et al.'s (2012) RR model, I proceed to compare the merits of each respective theory by applying both frameworks to the phenomenon of moral decision-making among younger and older adults. My analysis reveals that RR subsumes the explorationexploitation trade-off, and therefore bears greater explanatory power than the EE model-it explains what EE is meant to explain, plus more. Lastly, I discuss the theoretical benefits of RR as well as potential empirical directions for future research seeking to explain aging trends in moral decision-making.

div.head: Moral Decision-Making Across Adulthood
div.p: Reader, let us return to the Garden of Eden, where Adam and Eve committed a moral transgression against God, resulting in their exile from paradise (NIV Bible, 2011, Genesis 3).

Ironically, the act of eating the forbidden fruit resulted in the awareness of the knowledge of good and evil. Indeed, this story depicts humans' capacity to sin (hence the label "original sin"), but it is not the oldest writing on morality. The first writings on the topic tracked who owed what RELEVANCE REALIZATION,AGING, to whom among merchants in ancient Mesopotamia (Haidt, 2008). Fast forward thousands of years, and we see that despite advances in science, moral insights are largely stable. Haidt offers a functionalist definition of morality, defining it as systems of "interlocking sets of values, practices, institutions, and evolved psychological mechanisms that work together to suppress or regulate selfishness and make social life possible" (p. 7). Social scientists have been especially curious in their studies of human cooperation. Morality is undoubtedly implicated in explaining patterns of how we relate to one another.

The planet is becoming increasingly interconnected. At the same time, births are declining, and we are seeing aging populations across the globe (World Health Organization, 2022). Not only should we care about moral decision-making as a stable category of study, but given our populational reality, we should pay particular attention to moral decision-making patterns as we age. This is an especially intriguing line of inquiry considering that older adults are perceived as more moral and as knowing what is moral in Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich, Democratic (WEIRD) and non-WEIRD societies (including Canadians; Sorokowski et al., 2023), hinting at a cross-cultural phenomenon. In this section, I draw from Daley & Kensinger's (2021) review to outline aging trends as they relate to moral decision-making. Given the focus of this paper is not the synthesis of moral decision-making research across adulthood, but instead, the application of an emerging framework of cognitive function to this domain of study, I will largely be relying on an existing review to extract insights on the mechanisms underlying moral decision-making across younger and older adults.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, healthy younger and older adults differ in their performance across a range of tasks. This observation extends to decision-making in the context of sacrificial moral dilemmas, scenarios in which an agent must decide whether they are willing to sacrifice RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 10 one individual to save five others. In such paradigms, older adults tend to make more nonutilitarian decisions (Huang et al., 2021b;McNair et al., 2019; see also Daley & Kensinger, 2022). There are several inputs into the observed age difference in these dilemmas, including cognitive, neural, and socioemotional contributors (Daley & Kensinger, 2021). Cognition peaks in young adulthood, and aging is associated with cognitive decline even in healthy individuals.

Compared to younger adults, older adults maintain or show an increase in crystallized intelligence, while their fluid intelligence begins to suffer (Tucker-Drob et al., 2022). But despite worsened performance on standard neuropsychological assessments that may paint a bleak image of cognition in older adulthood, when content is made to be socioemotionally relevant (e.g., remembering the death of Princess Diana vs. a mundane event around the same time), the performance of older adults begins to resemble that of younger adults (Duarte & Kensinger, 2019;Kensinger et al., 2014). This makes sense, considering that cognition in older adulthood is more sensitive to internal states, such as thoughts and feelings. The complexity here is particularly relevant to moral decision-making, which involves both cognitive and socioemotional processes.

The dual-process theory of moral decision-making (proposed by Greene, 2007) suggests that refraining from the utilitarian choice is reflective of an immediate emotional response when considering sacrificing an individual. In overriding this initial response, which requires slower and more controlled cognitive processing, a participant can make the utilitarian choice. Older adults' deontological decision-making is partially mediated by a self-reported experience of elevated negative affect when considering the dilemma (as well as a greater tendency for moral idealism;McNair et al., 2019). Thus, in accordance with Greene's dual-process account of moral decision-making, at least one study suggests that older adults may be less inclined to opt for the RELEVANCE REALIZATION,AGING, utilitarian decision given they are more affected by emotion when faced with these dilemmas.

Neuroimaging studies have also revealed that deontological and utilitarian reasoning rely more heavily on brain regions associated with emotional and controlled processing respectively (Bago & De Neys, 2019). Importantly, older adults may not have the cognitive capacity to override the "gut" emotional response, thereby selecting the easier and quicker deontological choice. Moral decision-making research has been critiqued for its use of stimuli like the Trolley Problem or Footbridge dilemma 2 as the moral choices one can make in response to the dilemma are confounded with the intuitiveness of the moral choice. In other words, are participants making a particular moral decision because that is their ethical leaning or because of how intuitive a given option is (Kahane, 2015)?

To account for the intuitiveness of the moral decision as a potential confound with the utilitarian and deontological choices (e.g., push fat man, refrain from acting), Huang et al. (2021b) presented participants with (non-trolley) dilemmas where both the utilitarian and deontological choices were intuitive. The deontological-intuitive scenario (i.e., whereby the deontological choice was the intuitive one) involved a vignette in which participants imagined being a doctor with five patients on the verge of death due to organ failure, and one young healthy patient. They had the choice of non-consensually transplanting the young man's organs into the bodies of the other five patients, killing one but saving five (utilitarian-counterintuitive choice), or not performing the transplant surgery (deontological-intuitive choice). Alternatively, the utilitarian-intuitive dilemma prompted participants to imagine being a waiter overhearing one of the frequent customers talking about going to jail soon but planning to infect numerous people with HIV in the remaining 48 hours of freedom. Knowing he is severely allergic to poppy seeds that would result in convulsions and hospitalization for at least two days, there were two choices presented: causing a serious allergy attack to prevent him from infecting others with HIV (utilitarian-intuitive choice) or doing nothing (deontological-counterintuitive choice). The results revealed that older (vs. younger) adults were more likely to make deontological choices, but this age difference only emerged for deontological-intuitive dilemmas. Thus, even when accounting for the intuitiveness of the response options in sacrificial moral dilemmas, we still see this age difference in moral decision-making styles (Daley & Kensinger, 2021).

div.head: Cognitive Decline Account of Age Differences in Moral Decision-Making
div.p: The age differences in moral decision-making might be attributable to declines in cognitive control, working memory capacity and subsequent reliance on brain regions that are more sensitive to emotional salience. Increased cognitive load has been associated with slower response times for utilitarian, but not deontological, decisions (Greene et al., 2008). This effect was evident in participants who endorsed utilitarian ethics as well as those who did not. Greene et al. (2008) suggest that reduced cognitive capacity could disrupt the necessary processes that lead to the endorsement of utilitarian decisions, arguing that their findings provide direct evidence that controlled cognitive processes play a role in utilitarian moral judgement. Other work has highlighted the role of cognitive control in overriding individuals' moral defaults of either honesty or dishonesty (Speer et al., 2021).

Further, processing speed accounts of cognition emphasize that older adults tend to perform more slowly across numerous measures of cognitive function (Salthouse, 1996). Older adults' ability to successfully execute complex tasks is likely compromised by their reduced ability to quickly synchronize the relevant cognitive operations. Salthouse (1996) uses a juggling metaphor to make this point: it is substantially easier to juggle (i.e., synchronize) when one can RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 13 throw and catch multiple balls (i.e., execute relevant operations) rapidly. In the study of moral decision-making, deontological (vs. utilitarian) decision-making could be argued to be of poorer quality if there is an imperative to save lives (Daley & Kensinger, 2021). Older adults' slower processing speed might prevent them from engaging the necessary cognitive operations to respond with the utilitarian choice.

Working memory theories suggest that decline in working memory capacity is associated with poorer performance on tasks that require mental manipulation of content. Thus, when older adults are required to keep track of all the task-relevant content when deliberating on their decision, their inability to do so may lead to greater reliance on affective heuristics, and therefore more deontological decisions, given all the necessary information is not available at the time of decision. Additionally, higher (vs. lower) working memory capacity has been linked to greater likelihood to sacrifice one to save many others as well as more consistent responding across numerous dilemma types (e.g., varying physical directness of killing, intentionality of killing, risk posed to subject, inevitability of death; Moore et al., 2008). Theories of inhibitory control posit that older adults have a more diffuse attentional spotlight, and experience increased difficulty in ignoring task-irrelevant stimuli (Hasher et al., 1991). Thus, more task-irrelevant content may be available in their attentional field. Compared to younger adults, older adults would be less capable of ignoring the emotional reactions that arise during the decision-making task (Daley & Kensinger, 2021). This would be in line with Greene's (2007) dual-process account, which argues that the deontological decisions older adults arrive at are partially attributable to their focus on the affective reaction elicited by the dilemma and inability to engage reflective processes to weigh potential outcomes 3 (Daley & Kensinger, 2021).

Overall, older (vs. younger) adults have more impaired cognitive control, and the agedifferences we see in moral decision-making might be due to the reduced cognitive capacity in older age. As a result, older adults may be less effective at inhibiting their emotional responses when faced with moral dilemmas.

div.head: Socioemotional Account of Age Differences in Moral Decision-Making
div.p: There are also differences between younger and older adults' socioemotional motivation.

Older adults have better memory and attention for affective (vs. neutral) stimuli, as well as a positivity bias, such that they are more attentive to positive (vs. neutral or negative) stimuli (e.g., Charles et al., 2003;Knight et al., 2002;Reed et al., 2014).

Socioemotional Selectivity Theory (SST) posits that as life becomes more time limited, like in the case of advancing age, motivations start to shift from future-oriented goals (e.g., career planning) to goals tied to emotion or meaning (spending time with family; Carstensen, 1992). It follows then that older adults prioritize positive relationships (Mather & Carstensen, 2005) and attempt to maintain social cohesion. This might be explained by age-related changes in generativity (Daley & Kensinger, 2021). While older adults exhibit a decline across numerous domains, generativity is not one of them. Priorities begin to shift from the here and now to consideration for the future of future generations (Carstensen, 1992;Erikson et al., 1989). For example, older adults are less likely to involve themselves in conflict, not because of indifference or incompetence, rather because their interpersonal problem-solving strategies (i.e., sensitivity to context, instrumental & emotion-regulation) serve to preserve positive relationships and reduce negative emotions (Blanchard-Fields, 2007;Carstensen et al., 2003;Charles & Carstensen, 2008 Mortality salience and positive mood inductions have been used to induce limited time perspectives and positivity biases in younger adults, shifting the motivations of younger adults to become more like that of older adults (Daley & Kensinger, 2021). Further, mortality salience and cognitive load inductions have been found to be similarly detrimental to moral decision-making, shifting participant responses toward the deontological choice at similar rates (Trémolière et al., 2012). Being reminded of impending death might have a depleting effect on cognitive resources due to attempts to suppress the distressing thoughts associated with inevitability, in turn, impacting moral decision-making. Older adults maintain a limited time perspective, thus, when they approach moral dilemmas, the limited temporal horizons-or more salient thoughts of death-are consistently affecting their decision-making.

If it was the case that cognitive capacity was what solely accounted for age differences in moral decision-making, then older adults with higher cognitive capacity should be performing similarly to younger adults. One study found that older adults with poorer executive functioning were endorsing responses that were like younger adults' (Maxfield et al., 2012). That is, among older adults, executive function positively predicted tolerance toward moral transgressors, with individuals exhibiting lower function endorsing greater punitiveness against bad actors. In the absence of cognitive decline then, aging might be associated with socioemotional shifts that lead to different moral decisions between younger and older adults. Following positive mood inductions, more utilitarian decisions are endorsed on the Footbridge but not Trolley Problem.

So, it is not just the emotional response elicited by moral dilemmas, but also the affective characteristics of the environment that an individual deliberates within that can affect one's moral decisions (Valdesolo & DeSteno, 2006). If older adults are more often in a state of emotion regulation that prioritizes positive mood, then we should expect them to endorse more utilitarian responses (Daley & Kensinger, 2021). But the tendency toward more deontological decision-making suggests that the emotional response elicited by the moral dilemma overrides the motivational context they are deliberating in.

Another motivational change that helps explain age differences in moral decision-making is the role of the self. As one ages, the quality of self-representation might shift, in turn affecting performance on tasks that contain social content. Compared to younger adults, older adults have better memory for self-(vs. other-) relevant content (Kensinger & Gutchess, 2017;Yang et al., 2012) and represent the self as more continuous across past, present, and future (Rutt & Löckenhoff, 2016). Involvement and representation of the self when making decisions might provide a different social context for older (vs. younger) adults to act within, partially explaining the observed age differences in moral decision-making. For example, compared to younger adults, older adults might experience reduced social distance, or greater overlap between their own self and the other individual in the moral dilemma, identifying with the victim more closely (e.g., "it could be me on that train track instead"), which in turn, influences their moral choice.

Socioemotional variables such as this may have greater weighting on moral decisions when considering iterations of the classic sacrificial moral dilemma (e.g., the victim is a friend), complicating the predominant belief that there is a "better" utilitarian choice to be made. Daley & Kensinger (2021) conclude their review by highlighting the ambiguity regarding where age differences in moral decision-making emerge from, stating that older adults' tendency toward deontological decision-making could be due to cognitive decline, motivational shifts, or an interaction of the two. Even when there are similar patterns across younger and older adults, it remains unclear whether younger and older adults are engaging the same mechanisms to arrive at the same decisions. At this point, it becomes useful to turn to frameworks that explain the psychology of aging more broadly to make sense of older adults' leanings toward deontological moral decision-making at both the level of specific cognitive and socioemotional inputs, and the unified process of moral decision-making. Thus, let us now examine Spreng and Turner's (2021) account of human aging, the exploration-to-exploitation shift in aging, which promises to do just that by condensing the two dominant aging trends (i.e., declines in fluid processes and accumulation of knowledge as well as affective shifts) into a criterion shift that favours "exploitation-based over exploration-driven mentation and action" (p. 2).

div.head: Aging and the Exploration-to-Exploitation Shift
div.p: Spreng and Turner (2021) make the claim that all volitional acts can be reduced to the choice to either exploit prior knowledge toward a more predictable outcome or to explore new sources of information that have more unpredictable returns. The authors bring together decision-making literature, with cognitive and affective aging theories, as well as research in the neuroscience of aging to propose a shifting mental mode hypothesis of aging, which postulates that exploration-exploitation trade-offs increasingly lean toward exploitation (over exploration) in older adulthood. As humans age, the fluid control processes which are necessary for fast and flexible engagement of cognitive resources decline. At the same time, prior knowledge of oneself and the world is on the rise. Spreng & Turner (2021) argue that these two trajectories favour an exploitative mental mode, in which the accumulating weight of prior knowledge representation strengthens the prepotency of exploitation over exploration-based decisions. This trend is RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 18 exemplified in expressions like, "been there, done that", whereby older adults are less enamoured by novelty (i.e., exploration) given the rich bank of knowledge (e.g., facts, experiences) they can draw from (i.e., exploitation). Affective changes in older adulthood might also produce an exploitation bias in older adults. Aging is associated with more reliance on positively valenced information and prior knowledge when faced with decision-making tasks (Carstensen et al., 2006), reflecting a shift from exploration to exploitation-based cognition.

When making decisions, individuals can select a known option or search for new, unknown options. One's environmental (e.g., resource availability/predictability, extraction costs, win/loss probabilities, time horizons, internal/external location of search), individual (e.g., demographics, cognitive/physical/psychological abilities, personality, neurobiology), and social factors (e.g., social competition/cooperation, availability/communal access to knowledge) determine the mental mode threshold to switch between exploration and exploitation.

The trade-off between exploration and exploitation is grounded in patterns of age-related changes in the brain, including declines in fluid cognition that is needed for directed exploration and accumulation of knowledge throughout a lifetime that reduces the informational value of exploration. These two trends can be consolidated as one unified trajectory, offering a more comprehensive view of cognitive aging. To assess for the combined influence of these trajectories, the relative weighting of each trend must be measured along a single dimension. The choice to exploit (vs. explore) provides an index of the summative influence of cognitive control processes, prior knowledge, and affective influences involved in producing that outcome. Thus, "the threshold at which an exploration-exploitation trade-off occurs, can provide a marker of how these capacities intersect and combine to shape goal-directed behavior" (p. 5). Spreng and Turner (2021) argue that the dual trajectories of cognitive aging bias older adults toward exploitation-based decision-making, as evidenced by their higher threshold to shift from exploitation to exploration.

div.head: Reduced Cognitive Control in Older Adulthood
div.p: Older adults prefer known vs. unknown choices in economic games (exploit), while younger adults are keener to investigate unknown possibilities that have the potential for greater reward (explore; e.g., Harlé & Sanfey, 2012;Roalf et al., 2012). This strategy can be influenced by inducing cognitive load; when control demands increase, younger adults begin to make more known decisions, shifting their exploratory search to an exploitative one. Baror and Bar's (2016) series of experiments suggest that although activation of knowledge associations is an exploratory process by nature, under high cognitive load, associated activation becomes more confined to the more immediate (or accessible) associations. Cognitive control demands play a role in the selection of exploration vs. exploitation, as well as the ability to flexibly switch between the two strategies (Hills et al., 2010;Logan, 2004).

Older adults' propensity tendency toward exploitative behaviours may be explained by declines in cognitive control (Mata & von Helversen, 2015). Performance in classic search and decision-making paradigms reveals a differential age effect, with older adults spending more time exploiting what they know (see Spreng & Turner, 2021). Both exploration and exploitation can be goal-directed in nature and hinge on cognitive control processes. When engaging the exploitation mode, "cognitive control is needed to maintain the search cue, sustain attention while searching through available knowledge stores, and suppress irrelevant prior knowledge" (p. 5). However, across most contexts, greater cognitive control is needed to engage the exploration (vs. exploitation) mode. Given aging is linked to declines in cognitive control, it makes sense that the choices individuals opt for become increasingly biased toward exploitation.

div.head: Increased Knowledge in Older Adulthood
div.p: The expanding knowledge repertoire of older adulthood is among the cognitive architectural shifts in aging (Spreng & Turner, 2021). As experience with the options available in the world increases, the value of untested options decreases, and as such, the risks of exploring these unknown choices with uncertain outcomes increases (Walker et al., 2019). An agent ought not to waste cognitive resources on exploration if they are satisfied with the reward to come and have nothing to gain by exploring other possibilities. Older adults take advantage of their crystallized knowledge base rather than risking the exploration of new information, which carries the unknown possibility of being either advantageous or disadvantageous. On the other hand, younger adults are more inclined to explore the unknowns given they lack the relevant knowledge foundation.

div.head: Shifting Motivations in Older Adulthood
div.p: Older adults are less interested in new things, which may be explained by a reduction in the value of new information in older age. Further, the time horizon to extract new information and reduce the potential negative consequences of exploration shrinks for older adults (Carstensen, 1992;Spreng & Turner 2021). Statistically, there is less benefit and greater cost associated with exploration in older age. These factors interact with evolving affective motivations throughout aging. Due to older adults' predisposition to favour positive experiences, they may be inclined to exploit what is familiar and positively valenced prior knowledge (recall SST). Indirectly, this would mean restricting their search, or preventing or delaying a switch from exploitation to exploration. Spreng & Turner (2021) conclude there is converging evidence that older adults' bias toward exploitation emerges as a mental mode due to declines in cognitive RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 21 control resources, a vast network of knowledge and experience, and motivational changes, which combined produce (or at the very least favour) exploitation-based decisions.

Here, let us remind ourselves that Spreng and Turner's (2021) account depends on the claim that "every volitional act is the product of a choice to either exploit prior knowledge toward a more predictable outcome, or to explore new sources of information with less certain returns" (p. 1). However, there is evidence that this claim may be left partial. Interestingly, recent work in the cognitive sciences has theorized that the hallmark of cognition is the capacity to engage in relevance realization (RR) through trade-off relationships making use of opponentprocesses like the explore-exploit trade-off articulated by Spreng and Turner's (2021) unified account of aging. Indeed, the explore-exploit trade-off that constitutes the backbone of their theory is but one of the trade-offs outlined by the theory of RR, which proposes a total of four trade-offs rather than just one (Vervaeke et al., 2012). To the degree that Spreng and Turner's framework was explicitly set to be a comprehensive theory of aging but omits other potential trade-offs at play than just the explore-exploit trade-off, it ought to be integrated with the theory of RR. Doing so would ameliorate its possible theoretical blind spots while realizing its aim of accounting for aging trends in a more comprehensive manner. Our next task is to review the theory of RR and how the various trade-off relationships it proposes are constitutive of cognitive agency, before we embark on our discussion of how Spreng and Turner's model can be complemented by the theory of RR.

div.head: Relevance Realization as a Theory of Cognitive Function
div.p: Our discussion of RR must begin with a discussion of the "frame problem" in cognitive science, as RR was originally developed as a means of circumventing the frame problem. To this end, let us turn to a series of vignettes offered by the philosopher Daniel Dennett (1987) depict the importance and implications of the frame problem. Dennett's illustration begins with R1, a robot that was tasked with obtaining its spare battery from a locked room with a ticking time bomb. The battery happened to be placed on a wagon inside the room, and R1 pulled the wagon out, successfully obtaining the battery while failing to realize the bomb was also on the wagon, resulting in its extinction. Thus, R1D1 was developed to recognize both the effects and potential side-effects of its actions. Placing R1D1 in a similar dilemma prompted the robot to engage in deductive reasoning, realizing that pulling the wagon out of the room would not have implications for the colour of the walls-this process took too long, and the bomb went off.

Consequently, R2D1 was designed to differentiate between relevant and irrelevant side-effects, with the capacity to ignore what was irrelevant. Placed in a similar scenario, R2D1 sat and tagged each newly generated effect and side-effect of a course of action as relevant or irrelevant.

When the engineers yelled at it to do something, R2D1 explained that it was busy ignoring the thousands of implications it had found to be irrelevant; once more, the bomb went off. All three robots ran into the frame problem, falling short of R2D2, the fictional robot in Star Wars that was able to engage in problem solving without falling into a state of combinatorial explosion.

For our purposes, combinatorial explosion refers to a cognitive agent's attempt to conduct an exhaustive search of an indefinitely vast problem space with severely finite cognitive resources-like trying to count to infinity. One such familiar human experience of combinatorial explosion is that of an anxiety attack, during which a person becomes overwhelmed and unable to keep up with all the possible scenarios that may unfold. For example, when faced with the trolley dilemma, a person neither pulls the lever nor withholds from doing so, not because they made an active decision to do as such, but because they became paralyzed by the overwhelming combination of possibilities and implications, unable to put a "frame" around what they were RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL considering. Yet, how is it that most of the time in the day-to-day, cognitive agents can solve problems while evading combinatorial explosion? Indeed, this is the question posed by the notorious frame problem, which has confronted most theories of cognitive function to date (Dennett, 1987;Hovhannisyan & Dewey, 2017;Hovhannisyan & Vervaeke, 2022;Vervaeke et al., 2012).

The theory of RR was proposed as a solution to the frame problem. At any given point, just like Dennett's robot, we are bombarded with vast amounts of information and have limited resources to process it all. It is not cognitively feasible to realize what is relevant by conducting an exhaustive search of the problem space. As such, any real-world cognitive agent must be equipped with the ability to filter through irrelevant information without entertaining combinatorially explosive search strategies (Dennett, 1987;Hovhannisyan & Vervaeke, 2022;Shanahan, 2016). How do we focus on the relevant information by putting a "frame" around it? Vervaeke et al. (2012) argue that a theory of RR must meet two requirements to circumvent the frame problem. First, it cannot adopt a substantive definition of relevance in explaining how human cognition engages in RR, as relevance is a dynamic and evolving category analogous to biological fitness (Vervaeke et al., 2012). Doing so would be akin to trying to explain biological evolution by proposing a fixed criterion of fitness (e.g., physical strength, intelligence, etc.) and a set of mechanisms for realizing it-yet this is contrary to how evolution occurs. In their article, Vervaeke et al. 2012 with what is relevant, but the set of processes through which cognition is able to realize relevance, otherwise it risks committing a jingle fallacy by treating relevance, a dynamically evolving category, as one that is static.

The second requirement, according to Vervaeke et al. (2012), is that RR "must evade homuncular fallacies," meaning that the mechanisms used to explain RR cannot tacitly presuppose RR in their explanations (p. 12). For example, the philosopher Christopher Cherniak (1986) tried to explain RR in terms of memory compartmentalization, failing to notice that the processes by which compartmentalization take place presuppose the capacity to realize what is relevant. This is because compartmentalization "depends on relevance realization in the process of developing, selecting, and then compartmentalizing memory" (Hovhannisyan & Dewey, 2017, p. 5). Homuncular fallacies entail circular explanations and ought to be avoided in science.

So then, how does the RR framework meet these two requirements in its explanation of how cognitive agents realize relevance without succumbing to combinatorial explosion? The following exposition of Vervaeke et al.'s (2012) theoretical rationale will illustrate this point, preparing us for our forthcoming discussion on moral decision-making and RR.

div.head: RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 25
div.p: To begin, we find that cognitive agents are normally confronted with problems in their interactions with the world (e.g., finding food). We also find that it is possible to interact with each problem domain using distinct but complementary learning strategies aimed at achieving the same goal (e.g., eat leftovers or dine out). However, since no single strategy on its own can offer a one-size-fits-all solution (e.g., we always eventually run out of food, or restaurants cannot offer us seating when they become fully booked), we realize that the shortcomings of one strategy can be mitigated by pairing it with an opponent but complementary strategy in a tradeoff relationship and setting the pair to optimize for reward in an iterative and self-organized fashion. For example, we can solve the problem of finding food by eating the leftovers in our fridge but shift to dining out once we have eaten all the leftovers.

Importantly, we also find that cognitive agents are normally confronted not just with a single problem but a problem landscape that involves a cognitive economy of competing goals and problems, and associated opponent-processes facing the agent (e.g., hunger, thirst, procreation, threat avoidance). Therefore, a cognitive agent must be equipped with the capacity to prioritize competing goals to cope with its complex and ever-evolving situation, and the mechanisms for goal prioritization should likewise be realized through opponent-processing, to render the optimization of prioritization in each of the domains possible. It is the optimization of reward across the various problems and timescales at which the agent is operating that ultimately results in the agent realizing what is relevant in a "context-sensitive, evolving, and self-organized fashion in relation to [its] situated interaction with the environment" (Hovhannisyan & Vervaeke, 2022, p. 13). In other words, optimizing for reward in this manner allows the agent to flexibly shift goals and strategies (e.g., from seeking food to seeking water or avoiding threat) as its problems evolve based on its interactions with the world and environmental feedback.

div.head: RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 26
div.p: We find that an opponent-processing approach like the one outlined above allows us to explain how cognitive agents evade combinatorial explosion by limiting their search space based on the kinds of heuristic strategy being used (e.g., find food by eating leftovers). Additionally, since multiple strategies, rather than one, are at play, opponent-processing allows the agent to realize relevance with respect to a goal without remaining committed to a static definition of which strategies are relevant. This framework therefore meets the first requirement for a theory of RR, namely by concerning itself not with what is relevant but the processes by which relevance is continually realized. The RR framework is also important because by explaining cognitive acts in opponent-processing terms, it makes it possible to evade homuncular fallacies, thereby meeting the second requirement of a theory of RR.

To support the rationale of their approach, Vervaeke et al. (2012) seek to advance their RR theory on general grounds. Specifically, their theoretical task is not to explain how human cognitive agents realize relevance given their organization (e.g., which brain regions carry out RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 27 RR and how) but rather what kinds of processes must be in place to make successful interaction with the world possible for any type of cognitive agent. To use an analogy, the difference between a theory of RR versus a theory of how a cognitive agent does RR is the difference between a theory of metabolism (e.g., as a network of autocatalytic processes) versus a theory of how an organism achieves metabolism given its particular composition (e.g., engaging liver or kidneys or muscles). In this paper, I apply Vervaeke et al.'s (2012) general theory of RR to demonstrate that the way in which younger and older adults engage in moral decision-making is reflective of RR opponent-processes, with older adults tending toward efficiency-(vs. resiliency) based processing more generally, as opposed to exploitation (vs. exploration) more specifically.
To understand what is meant by efficiency-based processing, though, we must first closely review the set of opponent-process pairs articulated by the theory of RR.

There are three opponent pairs (see Table 1) constraining the functioning of the cognitive economy, enabling an agent to continually engage in RR in an ongoing and contextually sensitive fashion. The first is Cognitive Scope, which trades off demands for special-purpose learning with general-purpose learning. This constraint optimizes for the applicability of an agent's information to its problem landscape. Put differently, applicability refers to the relevance of an agent's frames (or knowledge) to its context, which is being realized through the trade-off between special-purpose learning and general-purpose learning. On the one hand, specialpurpose learning involves the high-rigour processing of information in one domain with the possibility of finding reward but is metabolically costly. The risk here is that there might not be sufficient reward within that domain to "break even" (Hovhannisyan & Dewey, 2017, p. 6). On the other hand, general-purpose learning is metabolically cheap as it involves low-rigour information processing across multiple domains. However, in this case, there exists a potential RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 28 cost of forfeiting the rigorous examination of domains that yield high rewards. Hard commitment to either special-or general-purpose learning is disadvantageous to the agent, but the pairing of these strategies in a trade-off relationship can optimize for applicability in a self-organized fashion that mitigates the risks of either one. Consider for example a Swiss army knife as opposed to a kitchen knife, a screwdriver, or a hammer. One is a general-purpose tool that can be used across a range of contexts, while the others are fitted to specific contexts. It would be appropriate to carry a multipurpose knife when embarking on a trip along unfamiliar roads. But cooking would call for a kitchen knife, fixing the cabinet door for a screwdriver, and hanging up a new painting for a hammer. As cognitive agents, we have the capacity to engage in trade-off processes, in this case, trading off special-and general-purpose strategies, to effectively optimize for what a given context calls for (e.g., do I use my Swiss army knife to slice an apple, or do I grab a kitchen knife?). (Vervaeke et al. 2012). When new and pressing needs arise (e.g., avoiding harm), a system prioritizes by focusing on meeting this urgent need. Once this need is met, it can then diversify its attentional resources and attend to other needs in the given context (e.g., hunger). When faced with the trolley dilemma, a hungry agent will likely override the imperative to satiate their hunger by seeking food, and instead focus on saving lives. Once the existential emergency is resolved, they can proceed to attend to their need for food. Table 2 in Vervaeke et al., 2012 According to Vervaeke et al. (2012), governing these constraints are the higher-order For now, we ought to understand that relevance is not merely in one's head or in the environment, but a dynamical process between the brain and the world (Vervaeke, 2021). As I write this paper, part of me is pulled toward distractions, such as my neighbour's blaring Adele ringtone, my tea getting colder by the minute, and the presentation I must put together by Thursday evening. Another part of my attention is focusing and selecting, while engaging in the active process of varying what it is selecting for (Vervaeke, 2021). This provides me, a cognitive agent, with a salience landscape that makes it feel like I am here in this exact moment, in this state of consciousness, in this specific situation. This experience of connectedness to one's environment is fundamental for cognitive agency; without it, we are no different than pre- (Dennett, 1987;Vervaeke et al., 2012), and the theory of RR circumvents the frame problem. For this reason, RR is indispensable for explaining how cognition functions. To the degree that moral decision-making is a cognitively involved process, we can ask ourselves in what way RR is implicated in human morality. In other words, how do the processes of relevance realization manifest in moral decision-making? We are now ready to finally return to the question that started our journey.

We observe life engaging in RR at the level of the single-cell, and in more complex organisms like human beings (Hovhannisyan & Dewey, 2017;Hovhannisyan & Vervaeke, 2022;Vervaeke et al., 2012). One of the oldest intellectual topics plaguing laypeople and psychologists RELEVANCE REALIZATION,AGING, alike is that of morality. In the next section, we will be revisiting the phenomenon of moral decision-making across adulthood. The differences in younger and older adults' moral decisionmaking are well observed empirically. However, the theoretical explanations for why this age gap may exist appear fragmented or impartial, described much like the musings of "blind men" studying "different features of an elephant" (Wallach, 2010, p. 7). The explore-exploit shift proposed by Spreng and Turner (2021) offers a possible unified explanation of the age-related trends in this domain. However, in applying this model to the phenomenon of moral decisionmaking among younger and older adults, we will see how the model explicates some (but not all) of the RR dynamics. By mapping various trends in aging onto the different constraints of RR, I

seek to demonstrate the need to adopt a broader lens to fully explain the observed age differences in moral decision-making. Specifically, I make the case that as humans age, there appears to be a broader trend toward efficiency (vs. resiliency) more generally, as opposed to a trend toward exploitation (vs. exploration) more specifically. This, in turn, helps to better explain why older (vs. younger) adults lean toward deontological decision-making when faced with sacrificial moral dilemmas.

div.head: Realizing Relevance in the Face of Moral Dilemmas Across Adulthood
div.p: The EE model of aging would suggest that older adults' propensity for deontological decision-making in the context of sacrificial moral dilemmas is due to their bias toward exploitation. In this section, I outline mechanisms underlying moral decision-making as discussed by Daley & Kensinger (2021) and identify the trends that are suggestive of a bias toward exploitation, as conceptualized by Spreng & Turner (2021). In engaging in this process, we will 1) see that some of the trends that Spreng & Turner have argued to be indicative of exploitation or exploration are more appropriately captured by the Cognitive Scope or Cognitive Prioritization constraints of RR (vs. only Cognitive Tempering), and 2) that some of the observed age differences in moral decision-making cannot be accounted for by the EE model. Importantly, in outlining these cognitive and socioemotional trends in aging, we will see that there is a wider accumulative trend toward efficiency-(vs. resiliency-) based processing in older adulthood.
There is also a theoretical reason for why I interface EE with the RR model, which brings us back to the frame problem. Given the EE model is concerned with only one constraint that

div.head: Most of the age-related mechanisms implicated in moral decision-making can be
div.p: captured by the EE model-if not fully, at least partially. Older adults' decline in working memory capacity (which leads to the subsequent reliance on emotional salience in sacrificial moral dilemmas), is framed as the compression of information and integration of fewer choice options (Spreng & Turner, 2021). One way to look at this process being expressive of an exploitative mental mode is that relative to younger adults, older adults are more concerned with the "line of best fit" when faced with a problem, as opposed to the line that will effectively capture all the data points (Vervaeke et al., 2012). Therefore, the decisions they make are more likely to be informed by the general rules they have adopted (e.g., do not kill), serving as heuristics to lean on. In this way, older adults "exploit" the cognitive structures that are already in place. As well, older adults are less proficient in holding and manipulating information, which would allow them to opt for the most appealing choice after having sifted through all the available options. Consequently, they are more likely to rely on salient sources of information (e.g., emotions). It may be that the additional options apparent to younger adults are simply outside older adults' perceptual boundaries, and thus cannot be integrated as valid choice options. Alternatively, it could be that because younger adults are more limited in prior knowledge, they must engage in more cognitively taxing processes to arrive at their decision. Given older adults' decaying inhibitory control, task-irrelevant content, such as emotional reactions that may arise when faced with a sacrificial moral dilemma, are more likely to impact a decision. Spreng and Turner (2021) argue that older adults' reduced inhibitory control prevents them from overcoming their starting, exploitative, mental mode. We can reconcile these observations by viewing older adults' emotional reactivity as the prepotent response they cannot inhibit as effectively. Emotional goals become increasingly activated as we age and thus require less cognitive control to be kept in working memory (Spreng & Turner, 2021). Through repeated activation, these become consolidated within existing schemas; as such, emotional responding favours an exploitative mental mode-it is more metabolically efficient, compared to the alternative of exerting cognitive control to override the default response.

The RR framework provides a more intricate breakdown of this trend. First, we see that as the inhibitory mechanisms that downregulate emotional reactivity decay in older age, the focus on "System 1" processing (or emotionality) becomes primary. This shift in focus on System 1 processing thus implicates Cognitive Prioritization (i.e., focusing vs. diversifying).

Once there is a shift toward focusing, exploiting priors such as the emotional heuristics an agent has adopted throughout their lifetime becomes a more reasonable avenue to take, thus implicating Cognitive Tempering, which involves the trade-off of exploitation and exploration.

And since the agent has adopted an emotional heuristic, they have therefore opted for "line of best-fit" strategy (i.e., a form of data compression), which therefore implicates the trade-off between general-purpose vs. special-purpose learning (i.e., Older adults' slower processing speed may be feeding into deontological decisionmaking by way of preventing the necessary exertion of cognitive control to arrive at the utilitarian choice (Daley & Kensinger, 2021). Spreng & Turner (2021) do not directly discuss processing speed, but they suggest aging is associated with greater processing efficiency via lower control demands. As in, older adults are more likely to arrive at their decisions by drawing from existing information structures. Though the language is slightly different across these reviews (implicating a jangle fallacy), they both describe the same phenomenon. That is, older adults' decline in processing speed or increase in efficiency emerges from decline in cognitive control. This suggests an exploitative mental mode to the extent that slower processing acts as a unknown). In this trend, Cognitive Scope is implicated through general-purpose learning (data compression). The positivity bias can be viewed as a form of data compression because by viewing information in a positive light, a line of best fit that reduces ambiguity and noise is drawn; this comes at the loss of potentially important detail that is not necessarily positive.

However, Cognitive Tempering is (correctly) implicated in that the increased propensity to seek known rewards is a way of exploiting known priors. Importantly, both generalization and exploitation are indicative of a broader trend toward efficiency, once again suggesting that the tendency toward deontological decision-making across adulthood reflects a trend toward efficiency-based processing in older age.

As we age, we experience a shorter temporal horizon. Put crudely, death becomes a more realistic possibility. In the context of moral dilemmas, mortality salience has been shown to shift participants' responses toward the deontological choice, perhaps through the depletion of cognitive resources from attempts to suppress the distressing thoughts associated with inevitability (Daley & Kensinger, 2021). The EE model (Spreng & Turner, 2021) suggests that due to older adults' narrowing time horizons, there is a lower value attached to unknown information, and a higher value associated with social intimacy. Reasonably, this would reduce older adults' desire to engage in exploration as a means of finding rewards through novelty and instead promote engagement with what they already find meaningful.

Reconciling these points, we can see that the deontological choice is an expression of an exploitative mental mode to the extent that 1) depletion of cognitive resources due to attempts at suppressing thoughts of impending death pushes participants to rely on internalized rules (i.e., do not kill), 2) entertaining the utilitarian choice becomes more costly than what it is worth, as there RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 39 is less time to both consider the risks that may come with either choice and mitigate for costs if the plan goes awry, and 3) exploiting social connections becomes a means of cognitive offloading, such that, instead of having to engage in rigorous information processing alone, one can leverage social intimacy to disperse the task across numerous others (i.e., distributed cognition). In this case, the RR framework agrees with the EE model insofar that Cognitive Tempering is implicated in the trend of shrinking temporal horizons that may be feeding into deontological decisions. However, RR would suggest that the expression of a deontological choice that corresponds to reduced exploration via both depletion of cognitive resources and neophobia offers a "line of best-fit" solution (i.e., generalization), thus implicating Cognitive A commonly discussed trend in the aging literature is the accumulation of crystallized knowledge across the lifespan. This has not been discussed as a direct input into moral decisionmaking (Daley & Kensinger, 2021), but instead a general observation that older adults have a greater knowledge bank to draw from, even if they are not as apt at manipulating novel information (i.e., reduction in fluid intelligence). Spreng & Turner (2021) discussed this trend in the context of declining cognitive control (through poor updating based on new information and miscalibration of uncertainty) as well as gains in prior knowledge (including increased certainty and reward value for known options, and drawing from prior knowledge, like schemas, for current mentation). In other words, the EE model explains this trend in terms of the shift from exploration to exploitation. The RR framework agrees with the EE model in that poor learning and reliance on existing knowledge is an exploitative process. However, it also suggests that poor learning, and the expression of existing heuristics and schemas maps onto generalization (e.g., applying a "line of best fit" strategy), implicating Cognitive Scope as well. And since both Cognitive Tempering and Cognitive Scope are being implicated but neither is reducible to the other, this once again provides evidence that these individual processes reflect an increase in efficiency-based processing more generally, rather than an exploitative-based processing more specifically.

There are some processes involved in moral decision-making that are not directly captured by the EE model (Spreng & Turner, 2021), namely older adults' greater generativity and evolving representation of the self (see the Section on "Socioemotional Account of Age Differences in Moral Decision-Making"). The EE model cannot neatly be applied to the observation that older adults are more concerned with the future generation nor that older adults are less socially distanced from others, less self-biased, and perceive the self as more continuous (Daley & Kensinger, 2021). The authors discuss social phenomena across aging, consolidating these under the exploration to exploitation shift; however, this is limited to discussion of trends that reflect older adults' motivation toward affective goals (e.g., narrowing time horizons, positivity bias), leaving out two mechanisms implicated in the age differences in moral decisionmaking (i.e., generativity and evolving representation of the self; Daley & Kensinger, 2021). The application of RR to these trends likewise faces a similar issue, requiring an application of the theory to the social dimension, which has not been articulated by the authors, as RR is concerned with the agent and the world [as opposed to the agent and (an)other agent(s); Vervaeke et al., RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 43 2012]. If we find that RR is too limited to account for these trends, then the EE model, which RR subsumes, would also be too limited to account for it.

Generativity and the representation of the self are likely functions that emerge at the level of social cognition, and so they cannot be accounted for at the level of the individual alone. By definition, generativity involves a relationship with the younger generation. As well, older adults' reduced self-bias and social distancing is reflective of a prosocial tendency. Given we cannot directly apply RR to these trends, for now let us take a slight step back from the RR framework to assess whether these trends likewise reflect the meta-constraint of efficiency.

Recent work has explored the relationship between RR and the Big Five theory of personality (Hovhannisyan & Vervaeke 2022). The authors draw on a body of research that argues the five factors of personality can be accounted for by two higher-order factors, or metatraits: Stability and Plasticity (DeYoung, 2015). Specifically, the authors make the case that meta-traits Stability and Plasticity correspond to the higher-order constraints efficiency and resiliency at the trait (vs. state) level (Hovhannisyan & Vervaeke, 2022). Importantly, under this model, trait Agreeableness falls under meta-trait Stability and is referred to as a proxy for social stability (DeYoung, 2015). Agreeableness can be decomposed into two distinct systems: politeness, which accounts for the downregulation of antisocial impulses, and compassion, which accounts for the spontaneous bottom-up experience of prosocial impulses (DeYoung, 2015;

Hovhannisyan . If prosociality is an aspect of agreeableness via compassion, then the more compassionate one is, the more agreeable they are, and the more social stability they experience. Thus, if generativity and agreeableness are connected, and likewise, if agreeableness is implicated in perceiving self-other overlap, then given that agreeableness corresponds to meta-trait stability (DeYoung, 2015;Hovhannisyan & Vervaeke, 2022), which RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 44 essentially reflects the higher-order constraint of efficiency at the trait level, then an increase in generativity and a reduction in self-bias ought to correspond to an increase in efficiency (G. Hovhannisyan, personal communication, July 7, 2023). While both the EE model and RR framework are not directly applicable to these trends given their limitations in discussing social cognition, it still appears these two trends are reflective of an increase in efficiency-based processing, at least at the level of traits (vs. states).

Conversely, there are some aging trends Spreng & Turner (2021) highlight that do not appear to feed into moral decision-making. Regardless, for our purposes, it is worthwhile to consider how these trends are subsumed by RR. For example, older adults' mental flexibility manifests as a reduced ability "to shift search strategies based on changing response contingencies" (Spreng & Turner, 2021, p. reduced capacity for future planning and prospection maps onto general-purpose learning in that it calls for abstracted, low-rigour processing regarding the future, to extract general truths that can be applied across numerous contexts. Importantly, this trend also correctly implicates Cognitive Tempering, given that it is concerned with the interactional problem of projectability. Beyond what has already been discussed, a key limitation to consider is that RR is an emerging theory that lacks direct empirical testing. The only empirical test of this theory that I am aware of is contained within the pages of a dissertation that demonstrates relevance realization taking place at the level of individual differences in personality (Hovhannisyan, 2023). Using a qualitative, case-study approach, Hovhannisyan (2023) found that participants' Big Five personality traits were implicated in the adaptive and maladaptive ways they engaged with, or realized relevance, in the world (Hovhannisyan & Vervaeke, 2022). This dissertation was not a direct test of RR, but nonetheless revealed evidence in support of this theory. Notably, in the above section I have outlined how the cognitive and socioemotional processes involved in moral decision-making (which have been studied extensively -e.g., processing speed, working memory, mortality salience) can effectively be conceptualized through the lens of RR at the level of both subordinate and superordinate constraints, serving as indirect support for the theory.

Future research could undertake the novel task of directly testing RR machinery, bolstering its authority as a theory of cognitive function. As a starting point, I will propose potential paradigms that could elucidate the extent to which younger and older adults lean toward efficiency (vs. The exploration and exploitation trade-off has commonly been studied via information search tasks (Spreng & Turner, 2021). I suggest adopting a similar paradigm within the context of trolley dilemmas to study Cognitive Tempering, which deals with the interactional problem of projectability via the explore-exploit trade-off. Younger and older adults would be presented with the classic trolley dilemma with two primary choice options (i.e., pull lever or do nothing), as well as the opportunity to seek unknown, additional information prior to making a decision. In opting to seek new information, the participant would be directed to a page of clickable boxes, whereby each box would reveal content about the victims or situation (e.g., age, occupation, hobbies, how they ended up on the tracks, and so on). Considering older adults are more likely to seek known rewards, rely on priors, and are less interested in novel information, I would expect them to seek additional information to a lesser degree than younger adults, tending to make a decision with the information they already have (i.e., visual presentation of the classic trolley dilemma). Further, among participants who do seek more information, I would predict that older (vs. younger) adults would engage in the exploration of this new information to a lesser extent (i.e., selecting less boxes).

Cognitive Scope addresses the interactional problem of applicability by trading off special-and general-purpose learning. We can think of these opponent pairs as a line that captures all data points or a line of best fit, respectively. Older adults endorse deontological ethics to a greater extent than younger adults. Adopting rules such as "do not kill" and applying them across contexts may be indicative of heuristic-based reasoning. Heuristics are a type of data compression (i.e., generalization), while approaching different situations with different solutions are more reflective of data particularization (i.e., specialization). Participants could be presented with a series of dilemmas that vary features such as the physical directness of killing, risk posed RELEVANCE REALIZATION,AGING, to the subject, inevitability of death, and so on, much like in the work of Moore et al. (2008).

After responding to each dilemma, participants would provide ratings on various questions that map onto a generalization or specialization strategy, assessing the extent to which it captures their reasoning on a scale of one to seven (e.g., "I thought about as many decision and outcome combinations as I could", "I relied on my morals"). I would expect that older adults would endorse items that reflect general-(vs. special-purpose) learning strategies more so than younger adults. Further, I would predict that older adults would be more consistent in their reasoning across dilemma types, with younger adults showcasing more variability.

Recall that the interactional problem being tackled by Cognitive Prioritization is that of flexible gambling, a system optimizing its prioritization of cost functions through the strategies of focusing and diversifying. In the review of RR, I gave the example of a hungry agent holding off on eating when faced with an existential emergency of needing to save lives (i.e., focusing on the urgent need, then diversifying attentional resources to meet other needs). One plausible way to gauge participants' engagement with either strategy is by presenting them with the classic Trolley and Footbridge dilemmas, involving pulling a lever or pushing a fat man; these dilemmas would signify low vs. high emotional conflict scenarios respectively (M. H. Turpin, personal communication, October 14, 2023). Participants would be prompted to list the factors they considered in arriving at their decision. Given older adults' declines in working memory and inhibitory control, which implies a reduced ability for mental manipulation of content as well as greater focus on System 1 processing respectively (as discussed above), I would predict that they would generate 1) a fewer number of considerations, as well as 2) more emotionally charged considerations that are not directly relevant to the dilemma at hand (i.e., greater focus on personal emotions, relatability to victim) for both high-and low-conflict scenarios. In contrast, I RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 48 would expect a larger list of considerations from younger adults and greater diversity in the content they generate (i.e., demographic information of victims, personal feelings) for lowconflict scenarios, but performance that resembles older adults' more so for high-conflict scenarios, such that they demonstrate more flexible adaptation to the emotional context of the dilemma compared to older adults. This is not to say younger adults will not attend to emotional cues, but that the relative weight of emotionality will be diminished in this age group. As in prior literature, I would further predict that older adults would endorse deontological decisions more so than younger adults across dilemma types.

There are likely other ways of operationalizing the RR constraints. The task of this comprehensive paper was not one of proposing experimental paradigms, but of applying an emerging theory to moral decision-making phenomena across younger and older adults, and in doing so, demonstrating that the mechanisms underlying moral decision-making can be conceptualized as being reflective of efficiency-based processing in older adulthood.

Nonetheless, I have proposed three potential paradigms that could target each of RR's subordinate constraints in the context of sacrificial moral dilemmas, which ought to be taken as blueprints to build and expand upon. Revealing that older adults are engaged in general-purpose learning, exploiting, and focusing strategies when faced with sacrificial moral dilemmas to a greater degree than younger adults would be to show that older adults lean toward efficiency-(vs. resiliency-) based processing more so than younger adults. Future research could explore the possibility of conducting empirical tests of RR in the context of moral decision-making using such paradigms, or perhaps developing a singular paradigm that can effectively capture all four constraints (including the meta constraints).

div.head: RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 49
div.p: We further ought to consider that this comprehensive paper is limited in its discussion of 1) neuroanatomy and 2) non-sacrificial moral dilemmas. To address the first point, discussion of neuroanatomy was simply unfeasible for this project but will be integrated in developing this paper into a manuscript. Importantly, it has already been shown that RR machinery is implicated in both the brain's "firing and wiring", in other words, patterns of neuronal connections and patterns of neuronal activation (Vervaeke & Ferraro, 2013, p. 14). Thus, there is a high likelihood that the neuroanatomy producing the observed age differences in moral decisionmaking likewise ties back to the meta-constraint of efficiency. As for the second point, this paper limited the application of RR to sacrificial moral dilemmas to utilize an existing review that addresses the link between aging and moral decision-making (i.e., Daley & Kensinger, 2021).

Once again, this was done to keep the project contained. We ought to expect the same cognitive and socioemotional mechanisms informing moral decision-making in other types of moral scenarios, even if they do so to different degrees compared to what is elicited by sacrificial moral dilemmas. This line of reasoning likewise extends to more complex iterations of sacrificial moral dilemmas (e.g., the individual victim is someone you know); I would expect similar mechanisms underlying the moral decision, though implicated to varying degrees. Indeed, this is all speculation, and further expansion of this work is warranted to make such claims confidently.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Reader, I opened this text by telling you about the paramecium, a single-celled organism that realizes relevance as it floats around in still waters. We fast forwarded by four billion years and found ourselves in the Garden of Eden, where the cell was now man, and man was a selforganizing cognitive agent who sinned before God, with the transgression itself being the awareness of morality. We then delved into the literature on moral decision-making across younger and older adults, closely examining how the cognitive and socioemotional mechanisms that produce a differential age effect in sacrificial moral dilemmas are effectively captured by the Relevance Realization framework, an emerging theory of cognitive function that, as we have seen, subsumes the Exploration-Exploitation model of aging.

Across all the identified mechanisms involved in moral decision-making, older adults' leanings toward deontological decision-making could be mapped onto greater employment of generalization (vs. specialization), and/or exploitation (vs. exploration), and/or focusing (vs. diversifying). Thus, it is more plausible that the fundamental processes underlying moral decision-making across younger and older adults reflect a higher threshold to switch from efficiency to resiliency-based processing in older age (Vervaeke et al., 2012), instead of a higher threshold to switch from exploitation to exploration, as the EE model would suggest (Spreng & Turner, 2021). EE's theoretical precision and explanatory power can be improved by augmenting it with RR and the additional cognitive constraints it offers, including Cognitive Scope and Cognitive Prioritization as opposed to only Cognitive Tempering, as well as the higher-order efficiency-resiliency trade-off.
