The variables involved in the observed aging trends consequently can become more theoretically tractable, and our explanations of their underlying mechanisms less prone to logical fallacies, such as the jingle-jangle fallacy (Grossmann et al., 2020), as well as less likely to confront the notorious frame problem of cognition.

However, there is no reason to believe that the RR framework is a complete theory. What if cognition involves more processes than the trade-offs articulated by RR? That is, trade-offs beyond exploration vs. exploitation, general-purpose vs. special-purpose learning, and focusing vs. diversifying? If this is the case, then adopting RR as it currently stands would, much like EE and other theories of cognition, risk running into the frame problem. Importantly, the authors RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 51 have already made this point (Vervaeke et al., 2012), expressing that the RR framework is meant to serve as a viable starting point for a theory of relevance realization as it pertains to cognition, and suggesting there may indeed be other constraints implicated in how cognition realizes relevance. Nevertheless, the authors view all possible constraints as being encompassed under the fundamental trade-off between efficiency and resiliency (G. Hovhannisyan, personal communication, November 7, 2023).

Reader, let us return to the Garden of Eden one last time and rewind to the moment that God created Adam. Upon doing so, God decided that man should not be alone and so he created Adam's ezer k'negdo. This term is often incorrectly translated to a suitable or fitting helper.

However, the literal translation of this Hebrew term is a helper who is against him. In other words, Eve was created to fulfill the function of an oppositional, but complementary force to Adam. From the paramecium to our archetypal sinners, Adam and Eve, we see life realizing relevance through opponent-processing. If human evolution indeed began with a single cell, then this final reflection should come as no surprise.

figure.figDesc: extend the evolutionary analogy by comparing the processes of relevance realization to the mechanisms of natural selection. Hovhannisyan and Vervaeke (2022) summarize this point as follows: Just as Darwin's theory dispenses with the project of theorizing about biological fitness and instead explains how biological fitness is continually realized in an evolving and self-organized fashion through the mechanisms of natural selection, so too does Vervaeke et al.'s (2012) theory of RR dispense with theorizing about relevance as such; instead, it attempts toexplain the mechanisms by which relevance-i.e., cognitive fitness-is continually realized in a self-organized, evolving, and dynamically situated fashion. We may refer toVervaeke et al.'s (2012) approach to the frame problem as an "opponent-processing" approach that replaces the computational metaphor for mental functioning with the metaphor of the mind as a dynamically situated cognitive economy. (p. 13)The key implication here is that a theory of cognitive function should not concern itself

Finally, since the agent's cognitive economy consists of a host of (competing) opponent-processes that are adapted to a complex problem landscape, what counts as a relevant goal for the agent is likewise bound to shift based on the agent's interactions with the environment (e.g., once I satiate my hunger, I can refocus on editing my comprehensive paper). At no point is the capacity for relevance realization presupposed, but is instead explained as the optimization of reward through trade-off relationships between various opponent pairs.We see thatVervaeke et al.'s (2012) approach circumvents the frame problem theoretically by proposing a set of non-specific mechanisms (i.e., opponent-processes) that can realize what is relevant (i.e., put a frame around available information) without either adopting a substantive definition of relevance or engaging in combinatorially explosive search strategies.

The second constraint is Cognitive Tempering, optimizing for the projectability of an agent's information by pairing exploitation and exploration. Exploitation maximizes on easy and immediately available rewards, risking opportunities that might not be readily graspable. Exploration mitigates this risk by pursuing more, in turn, risking nearby opportunities at a higher cost. Consider a drive as basic as hunger. A hungry agent can seek food by eating what is available at home or going to the grocery store to get new items. By staying where one is (i.e., exploiting), there is the risk of foregoing potentially better sources of nourishment. But by seeking something novel (i.e., exploration), there lies the risk of losing what one already has and not gaining anything better either. I will later discuss how the EE model of aging (Spreng & Turner, 2021) makes use of this essential constraint (i.e., Cognitive Tempering) but omits the other necessary pairs of opponent-processes implicated in the human cognitive economy. RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 29 The final constraint is Cognitive Prioritization. When a system optimizes for Cognitive Prioritization, it gambles its resources through the trade-off of focusing and diversifying strategies. This constraint concerns the structuring and prioritization of numerous cost functions, as opposed to the heuristic optimization of individual functions

constraints of efficiency and resiliency, which manage the agent's overall cognitive economy from the top-down, unifying Cognitive Scope, Cognitive Tempering, and Cognitive Prioritization into a single system. Efficiency serves to reduce variation in the different possible paths of action the cognitive agent can opt for, thereby reducing entropy within the system's functioning. It encompasses general-purpose learning, exploitative learning, and focusing strategies. While it is less metabolically costly, too much efficiency risks the loss of long-term RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 30 adaptability to inevitable change. Resiliency complements efficiency by increasing the possibilities for action through special-purpose learning, explorative learning, and diversification strategies-and therefore increases entropy within the system. Resiliency allows a cognitive agent to adaptively self-organize its resources to fit an ever-fluctuating environment. Too much environmental variation would lead to chaos, depleting an agent's resources, and preventing adaptation to the problem landscape. By optimizing for efficiency and resiliency, the cognitive economy can redesign itself to fit to the environment as needed, realizing relevance "in a contextually sensitive and non-homuncular fashion" (Hovhannisyan & Vervaeke, 2022, p. 15). To further illustrate, we can think of efficiency as fitting ourselves to what is variant in the environment. Conversely, resiliency refers to fitting ourselves to what is invariant in the environment. While efficient processing from the lens of RR might look like a person wearing generic hiking boots on outdoor adventures to experience adequate mobility and traction across a range of possible terrains, resiliency would more closely resemble wearing mountaineering boots fitted with crampons to climb snowy mountain peaks. 5 Humans-cognitive agents, engage in a dynamic trade-off relationship between efficiency and resiliency, optimizing for reward depending on the problem domain they find themselves within. As we move forward in this text, I will argue that the cognitive and socioemotional mechanisms implicated in moral decisionmaking lean toward efficiency-based processing more broadly across the lifespan, in turn, manifesting as deontological decision-making in the face of sacrificial moral dilemmas.

programmed machines. RR explains how we can adaptively self-correct and change our frames over time, realizing relevance while evading combinatorial explosion in our strategies for coping with the inexhaustible information available in our world. At this point, Reader, it is reasonable for you to ask me, what is the link between RR, aging, and moral decision-making, if there is one at all? The existing literature on RR argues that the mechanisms underlying RR are fundamental for understanding how cognition functions (Vervaeke et al., 2012; Vervaeke & Ferraro, 2013a; 2013b; Hovhannisyan & Dewey, 2017; Hovhannisyan & Vervaeke, 2022). The foundation of this claim is theoretically robust insofar as the frame problem confronts all theories of cognitive function

trades off exploration-exploitation (i.e., Cognitive Tempering), it necessarily confronts the frame problem by omitting the possibility of a cognitive agent engaging in generalization-specialization or focusing-diversifying trade-off processes (i.e., Cognitive Scope & Cognitive Prioritization respectively). A cognitive agent that is trading off only exploration and exploitation is like Dennett's robot (1987) being entirely indifferent to the applicability of its frames (special-vs. general-purpose learning) or the priority of its goals (focusing vs. diversifying). 6 A robot, and by extension a cognitive agent, that is incapable of trading off the opponent pairs within Cognitive Scope or Cognitive Prioritization is bound to run into the frame problem by employing combinatorially explosive strategies in each of these domains. By initiating this dialogue between EE and RR, I highlight the twofold need to 1) adopt a more comprehensive and nuanced view of human cognition in explaining phenomena like moral decision-making, in a manner that 2) reduces the likelihood of confronting the frame problem in explaining aging trends in human cognition.Daley & Kensinger (2021) explain older adults' deontological decision-making in terms of cognitive decline (i.e., implicating working memory capacity, inhibitory control, processing speed) and socioemotional motivation (i.e., positivity bias, temporal horizons, generativity, and representation of the self), dividing the age-related processes implicated in moral decisionmaking into two distinct arcs. On the other hand,Spreng & Turner (2021) divide the predictors of older adults' exploitative mental mode into three categories, including declines in cognitive control (i.e., implicating learning, working memory, inhibition, mental flexibility, future planning and prospection), gains in prior knowledge (i.e., reward predictability, associative processing, processing efficiency), and motivation toward affective or meaningful goals (i.e., positivity bias, positive reward expectation, and narrowing time horizons).

Importantly, from the RR point of view, information compression is a function of Cognitive Scope, not Cognitive Tempering, because this process is concerned with the interactional problem of how to fit data, not the interactional problem of whether to rely on priors by forfeiting the pursuit of meaningful opportunities that may be out of reach (or even deemed as unnecessary). Recall that the opponent pairs of Cognitive Scope are general-and special-purpose learning, with the pairs concerning the low-rigour (i.e., extract the best-fit trend) and high-rigour (i.e., track all the data points) processing of information, respectively. In light of the distinctions made known by the RR framework, the EE model appears to conflate Cognitive Tempering with Cognitive Scope in outlining the application of declining working memory in older adulthood. Significant constraints in working memory capacity make data particularization (i.e., specialization, such as the line that fits all data points) far less probable, and data compression (i.e., generalization, such as the line of best fit) far more probable as the primary style of processing. Under cognitive constraint, it is more feasible to rely on rules (i.e., generalizations) such as "do not kill", than to weigh context-sensitive pros and cons when faced with a given moral dilemma (i.e., specialization). The RR framework agrees with the EE model insofar as the observation is a trend toward efficiency. However, the RR model makes a differentclassification of the trend as belonging to Cognitive Scope (vs. Cognitive Tempering), as per the interactional problem being faced: applicability, as opposed to projectability. RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 36

Cognitive Scope). Once again, RR agrees with the EE model insofar as what is observed here is a shift toward efficiency-based processing. However, it makes distinctions that allow us to effectively track the various interactional problems at play, by showing how not only Cognitive Tempering (exploitation), but also Cognitive Prioritization (focusing) and Cognitive Scope (general-purpose learning) are all implicated in the decay of inhibitory control.

bottleneck on the maximum possible metabolic output of the agent, placing a greater demand on the exploitation of priors, thereby implicating the constraint of Cognitive Scope through data compression, once again. This may manifest as exploiting existing schemas, gist-based knowledge, or general-purpose heuristics (i.e., generalizations; Spreng & Turner, 2021). While the EE model captures a trend toward efficiency-based processing, RR identifies the unique roles played by both Cognitive Tempering and Cognitive Scope insofar as efficiency subsumes both exploitation, a component of the former, and generalization, a component of the latter. The positivity bias and prioritization of emotional well-being in older adulthood may promote deontological decision-making as a means of minimizing the negative emotions elicited by sacrificial moral dilemmas. Spreng & Turner (2021) suggest that older adults' positively valenced and gist-based memories serve to promote known over unknown choices. For example, if doing no harm carries a positive connotation, older adults are more likely to select the choice RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 38 that realizes this bit of positively valenced information, thereby, exploiting what is known (vs.

Scope as well. Once again, the EE model identifies a trend toward efficiency-based processing, but RR refines this observation, recognizing the unique roles of both Cognitive Scope and Cognitive Tempering.Most timesSpreng & Turner (2021) andVervaeke et al. (2012) are in agreement, such that the EE model will recognize that Cognitive Tempering is implicated, but not consider the other constraints at play in regulating an agent's cognitive economy, like in the case of older adults' slower processing speed, declines in inhibitory control, positivity bias, or shrinking temporal horizons. Additionally, when accounting for the other possible constraints identified by RR, in at least one instance,Spreng and Turner (2021) conflate Cognitive Tempering with other constraints (i.e., Cognitive Scope), overfitting the EE model, such as in arguing reduced working memory reflects an exploitative mental mode. A likely explanation as to why the researchers overextended their model is because they recognize that exploitation entails greater efficiency, and efficiency is the common theme that accounts for all the functional trends that have been discussed above. RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 40Overall, however, in light of the explanatory scheme offered by RR, we can see that the opponency of exploration-exploitation (i.e., Cognitive Tempering) alone is insufficient in explaining the cognitive and socioemotional trends that produce age differences in sacrificial moral dilemmas. This is because the interactional problems corresponding to each of the constraints are distinct and mutually irreducible, such that, the interactional problem being tackled in Cognitive Tempering, which is that of projectability, cannot be reduced to the interactional problem being tackled by Cognitive Scope, which is that of applicability, nor the interactional problem being tackled by Cognitive Prioritization, which is that of flexible gambling. Put differently, it is the case that exploitation entails efficiency, but it is not necessarily the case that efficiency implies exploitation, since it might instead imply generalization (Cognitive Scope) or focusing (Cognitive Prioritization). Importantly, exploitation, generalization, and focusing are all efficiency-based processes, revealing an aging trend toward efficiency (vs. resiliency) more generally, as opposed to a more specific trend toward exploitation (vs. exploration). This final observation leads us to conclude that the EE model alone is insufficient in explaining the age-related trends implicated in moral decisionmaking across younger and older adults and can effectively be augmented by the RR framework which offers additional cognitive constraints for consideration. With this in mind, let us now proceed to discuss the limitations of the EE model, RR as a theory of cognitive function, and this comprehensive paper.DiscussionAbove I discussed the age-sensitive cognitive and socioemotional inputs of moral decision-making as they relate to the EE model and RR framework. Across all the mechanisms discussed, older adults' greater tendency toward deontological decision-making was reflective of RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 41 greater efficiency, through greater employment of generalization (vs. specialization), and/or exploitation (vs. exploration), and/or focusing (vs. diversifying). Thus, our phenomenon of interest is not so much the reflection of a higher threshold to switch from exploitation to exploration(Spreng & Turner, 2021), but instead a higher threshold to switch from efficiency to resiliency-based processing. Across all the mechanisms underlying decision-making in the context of sacrificial moral dilemmas, at least one additional constraint than Cognitive Tempering (i.e., exploration vs. exploitation) was implicated in explaining age differencesnamely either Cognitive Scope (i.e., generalization vs. specialization) or Cognitive Prioritization (i.e., focusing vs. diversifying). Thus, given that the interactional problems corresponding to each of the constraints identified by RR are mutually irreducible, the EE model on its own is insufficient in explaining age effects in moral decision-making when considering the additional constraints identified by RR. If it is the case that RR can explain moral decision-making trends, then across all domains where the above discussed cognitive and socioemotional mechanisms are implicated, we should expect RR to successfully fulfill the task of explaining any age differences that arise.

3). This process reflects RR's Cognitive Prioritization constraint (i.e., focusing vs. diversifying) given it is concerned with the optimal structuring and prioritization of cost functions. Older adults' reduced mental flexibility can be framed as a greater tendency to focus their cognitive resources, given the limited capacity to diversify. Thus, reduced mental flexibility is functionally related to Cognitive Tempering (i.e., explore vs. exploit) only through the higher order constraint of efficiency (see Hovhannisyan & Dewey, 2017). Put differently, Cognitive Prioritization and Cognitive Tempering are related only because they are specialized instances of the efficiency-resiliency opponency, not because they are identical processes. Similarly, Spreng & Turner (2021) identify future planning and prospection as a sub-trend in older adults' decline in cognitive control, highlighting the "prospective foraging and mental simulations necessary for directed exploration" (p. 3). Recall that Cognitive Scope trades off demands for special-vs. general-purpose learning. Older adults'

However, if both Cognitive Scope and Cognitive Tempering are implicated, then the EE model is insufficient in explaining this trend, once again highlighting RR's edge in explaining aging phenomena, as one that is characterized by a broader trend toward efficiency-based processing.

resiliency) based processing by capturing the subordinate constraints (i.e., Cognitive Scope, Tempering and Prioritization), at least, in the context of sacrificial moral dilemmas. RELEVANCE REALIZATION, AGING, & MORAL DECISION-MAKING 46

body.note: These dilemmas have also infiltrated popular culture and are unlikely to be novel stimuli to research participants.

Interestingly,Moore et al. (2008) argue that the complexity of emotion-cognition integration processes that is evident in moral contexts is not effectively captured by the dual-process account of moral decision-making.

Related to older adults' interpersonal goals, one study found that older adults endorsed altruistic moral decisions that favoured social (over personal) interest to a greater degree than younger adults(Rosen et al., 2016). This effect was mediated by emotional empathy but not reasoning.
A purely efficient organism is a "jack of all trades" while a purely resilient organism is a "master of one."

For example, a robot indifferent to Cognitive Scope might employ a line of best-fit solution by treating other objects (like the battery) in its environment as explosive (like the bomb) in its attempts at evading the threat of extinction, thereby failing to replenish its reserves. Similarly, just as inDennett's (1987) illustration, a robot indifferent to Cognitive Prioritization might fail to determine which side-effects of its actions to tend to in a timesensitive manner, once again risking extinction.
